Amazonas Basin, Brazil

text:
The margin of the Foz do Amazonas Basin saw a shift from
predominantly carbonate to siliciclastic sedimentation in the
early late Miocene. By this time, the Amazon shelf had also
been incised by a canyon that allowed direct influx of sedi-
ment to the basin floor, thus confirming that the palaeo-Ama-
zon fan had already initiated by that time (9.5–8.3 Ma).
Above this interval, during a prolonged lowstand, Messinian
third-order sequences are preserved only in the incised-valley
fills of the canyon with no equivalent strata on the shelf.
Third- and fourth-order sequences younger than Messinian
are preserved on the shelf after sea-level rise above the shelf

text:
The Amazon Fan is a well-studied
feature. The fan has been a focus of
many academic studies, including a
major
project
(AmaSeds)
that
focused on surﬁcial sediments near
the river mouth of the subaqueous
delta and oﬀshore (see, e.g. Nittrouer
et al., 1986, 1996), as well as numer-
ous individual eﬀorts. For example,
Milliman
et al.
(1975)
investigated
the Quaternary sedimentation pat-
terns of this margin and showed that
during the interglacial highstand, the
river-contributed
sediment
largely
stayed near the river mouth, and was
then
deﬂected
north-westward
by
longshore currents. During the ensu-
ing glacial, when the sea-level low-
stand was reached (at 60–80 m below
present-day SL), the sediments were
directly point-sourced to the deep sea
through channels. Damuth and Ku-
mar (1975) also found the Amazon
fan sedimentation to be climatically
controlled and concluded that grav-
ity-controlled ﬂows were important
in sediment dispersal on the fan. By
extrapolation, they estimated the fan
to have been initiated in the mid- to
late Miocene. Later, mass-transport
deposits
(MTDs)
were
studied
in
greater detail and slope failure was
assigned an important role in fan
sedimentation (Damuth and Embley,

text:
Recent hydrocarbon exploration in
the oﬀshore Brazilian basins has led
to the availability of numerous high-
quality industry seismic and well-log
datasets to the academic community.
One of these basins, the Foz do
Amazonas
(Amazon
River
mouth)
Basin, comprises the Amazon deep
sea fan and the contiguous slope and
shelf
(Fig. 1).
Seismic
data
on
a
basin-wide scale from this basin were
made available to us through the
aegis of the Brazilian Ag^encia Nac-
ional do Petroleo, Gas Natural e Bio-
combustıveis
(ANP),
together
with
lithostratigraphic data from 22 wells
(with
biostratigraphic
information
from four wells). These data have
allowed us to interpret seismic facies,
and
biostratigraphic
correlations
have led to the construction of a
robust
chronostratigraphic
frame-
work for the region. This, in turn,
has permitted sequence stratigraphic
interpretations on a basin-wide scale.

text:
by the early Pliocene. Sequences younger than 3.8 Ma often
show fourth-order cyclicity with an average duration of
400 ka (larger scale eccentricity cycles) often preserved in
high-sedimentation-rate areas of river deltas. Mass wasting
and transportation of slope sediments to the basin began to
play an important role in sediment dispersal at least as far
back as the mid-Pliocene, after rapid progradation had
produced steeper slopes more prone to failure.

text:
1981). Maslin et al. (1998) attributed
the presence of up to 200-m thick
Quaternary MTDs to two diﬀerent
mechanisms: namely, destabilization
of the mid-slope gas hydrates during
lowstands leading to slope failure,
and ﬂushing of the slope following
deglaciations.
More
recently,
Reis
et al. (2010) concluded that large-
scale mass-transport processes in the
middle fan were also triggered by
gravitational
compression
of
fold-
and-thrust belts induced by gravity
tectonics.

text:
Based on Andean and sub-Andean
stratigraphic considerations, Camp-
bell et al. (2006) dated the transcon-
tinental
Amazon
drainage
system
onshore at ~2.5 Ma. However, after
oﬀshore industry wells became avail-
able, Figueiredo et al. (2009) con-
cluded, based on two wells on the
outer shelf and uppermost fan, that
the transcontinental drainage system
was in place as far back as 11.8 to
11.3 Ma
(updated
to
10.5 Ma
on
new
time-scales;
Figueiredo
et al.,
2010), as had been suggested by ear-
lier stratigraphic studies (e.g. Da-
muth
and
Kumar,
1975;
Hoorn,
1994; Hoorn et al., 1995; Figueiredo
et al., 2007). Thereafter, Latrubesse
et al. (2010) proposed an alternative
model for the palaeohydrological his-

text:
Fig. 1 Map showing the location of the Amazon shelf, slope and fan and the avail-
ability of seismic lines throughout the offshore Foz do Amazonas Basin. The extent
of the Palaeogene–early Neogene carbonate platform (as indicated by the seismic
data) is shown with the brick pattern. All available industry-drilled wells are
shown; only four of these (1–4) have biostratigraphic data that were used to con-
struct the age model of the basin (well 5 was used for log correlation only). The
locations of Figs 3–5 are shown by bold lines. Dashed blue line indicates the offlap
break (the modern effective shelf edge). Wells with a gradational transition between
carbonate and siliciclastic deposition are shown in green and those with an abrupt
transition are shown in blue.

text:
tory of the Amazon inland basins
during the late Tertiary. They revised
the results of Latrubesse et al. (1997,
2007) to conclude that ‘it was during
the early Pliocene that the Amazon
ﬂuvial system integrated regionally
and acquired its present appearance,
and also when it started to drain
water and sediments on a large scale
to the Atlantic Ocean’.
In this article, we present a sum-
mary
of
a
basin-wide
seismic
sequence stratigraphic study from the
Foz do Amazonas Basin and discuss
the events that led to the cessation of
the
predominantly
carbonate
sedi-
mentation
in
the
mid-Neogene
(named the Amapa carbonates) and
the shift to predominantly siliciclastic

We
have
constructed
the
chrono-
stratigraphic
model
for
the
basin
from four industry boreholes located
on the shelf and on the upper Ama-
zon fan. The well provided to us by
Petrobras (well 3, Fig. 1) is located
on the mid-shelf and also on one of
our key seismic lines. In addition,
Figueiredo et al. (2009) included bio-
stratigraphic
data
from
two
wells
(wells 2 and 4 on Fig. 1) on the

text:
outer mid-shelf and on the upper-
most part of the fan. A fourth well
with biostratigraphy was provided in
a report by ANP (well 1). These data
allowed us to assign ages (calibrated
to the most recent astronomically
tuned Neogene time-scale update of
Hilgen et al., 2012) to key horizons
on the closest seismic proﬁles to the
boreholes (Fig. 2), which were then
cross-correlated through seven cross-
cutting seismic lines throughout this
region.
Biostratigraphic
tie
points
also allowed us to extrapolate ages
of other key horizons (identiﬁed as
sequence boundaries by us on the
seismic proﬁles). On this basis, we
were able to assign ages to seismic
sequence boundaries (these SBs are
designated A through K in Figs 3–6).
This indicates that a nearly complete
record of sea-level changes in the late
Pliocene–Pleistocene is represented in
the younger part of this section.

text:
Figure 1 shows all of the currently
available
high-quality seismic
data
(~170 seismic lines) from the Foz do
Amazonas Basin and the locations of
40 exploratory wells. For this sum-
mary, we used seven key overlapping
seismic
lines
indicated
in
red
in
Fig. 1. Our methodology consisted
of
standard
practices
followed
in
seismic sequence interpretations (e.g.
Vail et al. in Payton, 1977). On seis-
mic lines distal to the Amazon palaeo-
canyon, the carbonate sedimentation
terminates abruptly, to be overlain
by siliciclastic sediments. Here, an
age
within
nannofossil
biozone
NN10 (ranging from 9.5 to 8.3 Ma)
is indicated for the transition from
carbonate to siliciclastics, thus pro-
viding evidence that carbonate depo-
sition continued at least during the
time span of biozone NN10 (Fig. 2).
However, in well 1, which is the clos-
est mid-shelf well to the mouth of
the palaeo-Amazon River, this tran-
sition is not abrupt but gradational,
which suggests that at least some ter-
rigenous material was available to
the
system
as
early
as
the
early
Miocene, dated in the well report as
biozones NN3 and NN4 (~18.3 to
15 Ma; Fig. 2). The same type of
transition can be seen in a number of
other wells (green dots in Fig. 1) that

model of the Amazon Basin. In all wells, the cessation of carbonate sedimentation occurs within biozone upper NN10 or just
below NN11, leading us to assign an age range of 9.5 to 8.3 Ma to this diachronous event. (Well 1 data courtesy of ANP; wells 2
and 4 after Figueiredo et al. (2009); and well 3 courtesy of Petrobras).

platform edge and thus the ﬁnal ces-

Above the Horizon A unconfor-
mity (the top of the carbonate plat-
form),
the
number
of
sequences
preserved depends on the location.
Proximal to the Amazonian sediment
supply
route,
the
Messinian
sequences
preserved
include
those
with SBs assigned ages of 6.8 and
5.6 Ma. Both third- and fourth-order
sequences are discernible in the youn-
ger part of the section because of the
increase
in
sediment
supply
rates
enabling the preservation of higher
frequency cycles. SBs can be assigned
to 3.8 Ma (D) in the late Zanclean,
3.2 Ma (E) and 2.8 Ma (F) in the
Piacenzian, 2.4 Ma (G) and 1.8 Ma
(H) in the Gelasian, 1.4 Ma (I) in the
Calabrian,
and
0.78 Ma
(J)
and
0.4 Ma (K) in the Ionian. These
higher order cycles are manifest on
several dip lines and mostly represent
an average of ~400 ka cyclicity. Both
type 1 and type 2 sequence bound-
aries
(SBs)
are
discernable.
We
believe that discriminating between
type 1 and type 2 SBs is a useful con-
cept as major erosional events are all
associated with type 1 boundaries.
Type1 SBs include G, H, I, J and K
that are all associated with sea-level
falls below the palaeo-shelf edge. The
G and H SBs are also associated with
extensive canyon cutting that is evi-

text:
Fig. 5 Strike seismic line on the distal shelf proximal to the palaeo-Amazon canyon. It shows a canyon-size broad channel cut
at the top of biozone NN10 (Horizon A, or 9.5–8.3 Ma). The next identifiable Horizon is dated above the top of NN11 (Hori-
zon C or 5.6 Ma SB). Thus, the canyon fill may represent an additional sequence (B or 6.8 Ma sequence) as shown (see text
for discussion).

text:
Basin clearly show that the termina-
tion of carbonate deposition was not
a singular event basinwide with a
unique age, but had diﬀerent chro-
nologies depending on the location,
with
time
gaps
above
the
event,
which
could
also
be
of
diﬀering
durations.
Two
diﬀerent
processes
can terminate carbonate deposition:
a major sea-level fall (when the base-
line moves below shelf edge) can shut
down carbonate productivity for the
period of the lowstand. If the subse-
quent sea-level rise is too rapid, the
carbonate factory may not be able to
reestablish itself, or cannot keep pace
with the relatively fast rate of rise.
The other reason for cessation of
carbonate deposition may be simply
an increased inﬂux of terrigenous
material that overwhelms carbonate
productivity. In this basin, we sus-
pect that both processes were opera-
tive. A comparison of our data with
the
eustatic
curve
of
Haq
et al.
(1988) recalibrated here to the new
2012 time-scale (see Fig. 6) provides
a plausible explanation of the termi-
nation of carbonate deposition in the
latest Miocene and the reason for
diﬀering durations of missing section
on the distal shelf and nearer the
sediment inﬂux route.
After a Langhian-Serravalian high-
stand, a major sea-level fall occurred
at the Serravalian-Tortonian bound-
ary (Fig. 6). This was followed by
another prominent sea-level fall in
the mid-Tortonian (within NN10) –
the sea level remains relatively low
for several myr thereafter. It gradu-

metadata.source_doc: Terra Nova - 2013 - Gorini - Late Neogene sequence stratigraphic evolution of the Foz do Amazonas Basin  Brazil.pdf

text:
sediment inﬂux. SBs G and H are
also associated with strong canyon
cutting events (see Fig. 4). The oﬄap
break of almost all sequences above
SB G show collapse geometries indi-
cating that unstable shelf edges led
to mass wasting of the unconsoli-
dated muddy sediments. Some of the
shelf edges also show listric detach-
ments
(see
Fig. 3).
The
youngest
sequence at the very top shows the
initial stages of a shelf-edge collapse,
developing
incipient
listric
faults
where the collapse has not yet pro-
gressed. Just below that (between
SBs J and K), the shelf edge shows
chaotic internal geometries where the
gravitational transport has proceeded
further, but has not yet concluded
and may be ready for further col-
lapse and mass transport to the dee-
per basin. Sequences below (up to
SB G), on the other hand, show
abrupt termination of the topset beds
that indicates that mass movement of
material to the deeper basin has been
completed. Thus, the mass-transport
processes described for the Quater-
nary by several authors (e.g. Damuth
and
Kumar,
1975;
Damuth
and
Embley, 1981; Maslin et al., 1998)
were also operative in the older Plio-
cene sediments (and perhaps even
earlier, see also Reis et al., 2010;
Silva et al., 2010).

ally rises to its previous height in the
late Zanclean just before the 4.2 Ma
cycle (after undergoing at least two
more
prominent
ﬂuctuations
at
6.8 Ma and 5.6 Ma). The preserva-
tion of the older sequences is there-
fore more likely in the incised valleys
rather than on the shelf. This is what
we think is observable on a strike
line that traverses the main palaeo-
Amazon channel (see Fig. 5). The
next dated sequence above the A
horizon and on top of the channel
ﬁll is SB C (5.6 Ma), and thus the ﬁll
can be dated between these two lim-
its (it may encompass an additional
sequence at 6.8 Ma, tentatively iden-
tiﬁed as B). As the overall sea level
remained below the shelf edge estab-
lished during the Serravalian, we do
not record B and C sequences above
the carbonate platform top. There-
after, the D and younger sequences
are seen in all locations. Most of the
younger sequences (D through K)
show an average cyclicity of ~400 ka
(larger scale eccentricity cycles). Such
higher
frequency,
orbitally
modu-
lated,
cycles
are
seen
in
many
intervals
in
the
geological
record
where sedimentation rates were high
enough to preserve and resolve them.
As
mentioned
earlier,
Campbell
et al. (2006), based on their review of
the Amazonia lowlands, came to the
conclusion
that
modern
Amazon
River initiation cannot be older than
late
Pliocene
(~2.5 Ma).

(2010) further criticized Figueiredo
et al. (2009) who, based on oﬀshore
data, favoured an older age of late

Fig. 6 Chronostratigraphic chart showing standard stages, planktonic foraminiferal
and nannofossil zones, long- and short-term (third-order) sea level curves (after
Haq et al., 1987 – the long-term curve is estimated assuming an ice-free world
throughout) and mostly fourth-order cycles of Hardenbol et al. (1998), all recali-
brated to Hilgen et al.’s (2012) time-scale. Seismic-stratigraphic sequences (A
through K and their correlated or inferred ages) identified along the Amazon Basin
margin (this study) are shown in the right column. The third-order sea-level curve
in the middle column does not show fourth-order cycles (namely, F, I and K SBs
shown in the two columns to the right).

Miocene (~10.5 Ma) for the initia-
tion of a transcontinental Amazon
River. Here, we have shown that
there was already a prominent can-
yon-size channel associated with SB
A (9.5–8.3 Ma) and thus, the trans-
continental
palaeo-Amazon
River
system should be at least that old.
We
agree
with
Figueiredo
et al.
(2010) that the onset of a transconti-
nental Amazon river may date back
to the mid-Tortonian, only a few
millions years later. On the basis of

rate
measurements

the
depositional
accommodation

text:
space and outbuilding of the system.
Thus, it is our conclusion that the
beginning of the Andean uplift that
inﬂuenced Amazonian sedimentation
on the oﬀshore shelf is considerably
older than 2.5 Ma and perhaps is no
younger than 5.6 Ma. This agrees
with the ﬁndings of Steinmann et al.
(1999)
and Garzione
et al. (2008)
who identiﬁed a major phase of An-
dean uplift at 9.5–6 Ma and 10–
6 Ma
respectively.
On
the
other
hand, SB G (2.4 Ma) also seems to
be associated with signiﬁcant incision
on the shelf and increased sediments
in the basin (see Fig. 4). This SB is
also associated with major instability
of the shelf margin when it had built
beyond the previous carbonate shelf.
This may correlate with the changes
in
the
Amazonian
drainage
that
established the modern drainage sys-
tem dated by Campbell et al. (2006)
at ~2.5 Ma.
Also, based on inland data, Latru-
besse et al. (2010) proposed an early
Pliocene age for the beginning of the
Amazonian
transcontinental
drain-
age.
We
suggest
that
the
event
described by Latrubesse et al. (2010)
seems
to
represent,
instead,
an
important evolutionary stage of both
the onshore and oﬀshore Amazon
basins. The ﬁrst change in sedimenta-
tion rate (after horizon C, 5.6 Ma)
described in this study, points to a
more eﬃcient transcontinental river,
and may be equivalent to the event
considered
by
Latrubesse
et al.
(2010).
Recent geodynamic modelling by
Shephard et al. (2010) also favours
older dates for the establishment of
the eastward drainage of the Ama-
zon
river
system.
Dynamic
topo-
graphical modelling by these authors
demonstrates the mantle-convection-
driven subsidence and uplift of wes-
tern South America and progressive
eastward
tilting
of
the
continent.
Their palaeogeographical reconstruc-
tions show uplift in the west and
subsidence
of
central
and
eastern
basins from 14 Ma onwards, leading
to the initiation of a transcontinental
Amazon River.

text:
of sediment to the basin, conﬁrming
an early late Miocene initiation of
the palaeo-Amazon fan deposition
(by 9.5–8.3 Ma). A prolonged low-
stand in the Messinian allowed the
preservation of third-order sequences
only within the incised valleys of the
canyon with no equivalent strata on
the shelf. After the sea level rose
above the shelf edge in the early Pli-
ocene, sequences began to be pre-
served on the shelf once again. Late
Pliocene and Pleistocene sequences
often show ~400 ka cyclicity that is
common in high-sedimentation-rate
areas of river deltas. Shelf-edge mass
wasting and transportation of slope
sediments to the basin ﬂoor seems to
have played an important role in sed-
iment dispersal at least as far back as
the mid-Pliocene, once rapid progra-
dation had led to failure-prone stee-
per slopes.
